nexttext: These measures are called transports or transport plans. Given a measurable cost function $c: E \rightarrow \RR$, the cost of a transport $\mu$ is the integral $\int c \; d\mu$. The multi-marginal Monge-Kantorovich problem is to minimize the cost amongst transports, i.e. to solve
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="p_{i}(\mu)=\mu_{i}~{}\text{ for  }i=1,\dots,d." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>p</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>μ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> for Â </mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>d</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
There is  a huge literature for the case $d=2$, \emph{the} Monge-Kantorovich problem, see e.g. \cite{Vi03}, \cite{Vi09} or \cite{AmGi13} for an overview. The literature on the case $d > 2$ is more recent and less voluminous. For an overview the reader is referred to \cite{Pa14}. \\
For $d=2$,  a characterization of optimal transport plans is given by the concept of $c$-cyclical monotonicity, see \cite[Ch.\ 5]{Vi09}: under fairly weak assumptions on the cost function, a transport is optimal if and only if it is $c$-cyclically monotone. A transport  is $c$-cyclically monotone if it is concentrated on a $c$-cyclically monotone set $\Gamma \subseteq X_1 \times X_2 = X \times Y$, i.e. a set $\Gamma$ such that  for any pairs $(x_1, y_1), \dots, (x_n, y_n) \in \Gamma$ one has, with $y_{n+1} = y_1$,
prevtext: These measures are called transports or transport plans. Given a measurable cost function $c: E \rightarrow \RR$, the cost of a transport $\mu$ is the integral $\int c \; d\mu$. The multi-marginal Monge-Kantorovich problem is to minimize the cost amongst transports, i.e. to solve
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{}{{}}\inf_{\mu\in\cM(\mu_{1},\dots,\mu_{d})}\int c\,d\mu." display="block"><mrow><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">inf</mo><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\cM</mtext></merror><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>c</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Does such  a characterization also hold for the case $d > 2$? \\
We start with a definition with a built-in mini-theorem that is well-known for $d=2$ and similarly easy to show for $d>2$:\footnote{In order to show (ii) from (i) it is enough to deal with measures $\alpha$ and $\alpha'$ that assume rational values only. One multiplies both $\int c \, d\alpha$ and $\int c \, d \alpha'$ with the integer $\tau$ which is defined as the product of all the denominators appearing in the values of $\alpha$ and $\alpha'$. It is then possible to write $\tau \int c \, d \alpha$ as a sum of the form $\sum_{i=1}^n c(x_1^{(i)}, \dots, x_d^{(i)})$ and because of the assumptions on $\alpha$ and $\alpha'$ one can find permutations to write $\tau \int c \, d\alpha'$ as $\sum_{i=1}^n c ( x_1^{(i)}, x_2^{(\sigma_2(i))}, \dots, x_d^{(\sigma_d(i))})$.}

\begin{definition}
A set $\Gamma \subseteq E$ is $c$-cyclically monotone if it fulfills any of the two following equivalent conditions:
\begin{enumerate}[(i)]
\item 
 for any $n$ and any points $\bigl(x_1^{(1)}, \dots, x_d^{(1)}\bigr), \dots, \bigl(x_1^{(n)}, \dots, x_d^{(n)}\bigr)\in \Gamma$ and  permutations $\sigma_2, \dots, \sigma_{d}: \{1, \dots, n \} \rightarrow \{1, \dots, n\}$, one has
prevtext:
There is  a huge literature for the case $d=2$, \emph{the} Monge-Kantorovich problem, see e.g. \cite{Vi03}, \cite{Vi09} or \cite{AmGi13} for an overview. The literature on the case $d > 2$ is more recent and less voluminous. For an overview the reader is referred to \cite{Pa14}. \\
For $d=2$,  a characterization of optimal transport plans is given by the concept of $c$-cyclical monotonicity, see \cite[Ch.\ 5]{Vi09}: under fairly weak assumptions on the cost function, a transport is optimal if and only if it is $c$-cyclically monotone. A transport  is $c$-cyclically monotone if it is concentrated on a $c$-cyclically monotone set $\Gamma \subseteq X_1 \times X_2 = X \times Y$, i.e. a set $\Gamma$ such that  for any pairs $(x_1, y_1), \dots, (x_n, y_n) \in \Gamma$ one has, with $y_{n+1} = y_1$,
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\sum_{i=1}^{n}c(x_{i},y_{i})\leq\sum_{i=1}^{n}c(x_{i},y_{i+1})." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>n</mi></munderover><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>n</mi></munderover><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

\item 
any finite measure $\alpha$  concentrated on finitely many points in $\Gamma$ is a cost-minimizing transport plan between its marginals; i.e. if $\alpha'$ has the same marginals as $\alpha$, then
prevtext:
Does such  a characterization also hold for the case $d > 2$? \\
We start with a definition with a built-in mini-theorem that is well-known for $d=2$ and similarly easy to show for $d>2$:\footnote{In order to show (ii) from (i) it is enough to deal with measures $\alpha$ and $\alpha'$ that assume rational values only. One multiplies both $\int c \, d\alpha$ and $\int c \, d \alpha'$ with the integer $\tau$ which is defined as the product of all the denominators appearing in the values of $\alpha$ and $\alpha'$. It is then possible to write $\tau \int c \, d \alpha$ as a sum of the form $\sum_{i=1}^n c(x_1^{(i)}, \dots, x_d^{(i)})$ and because of the assumptions on $\alpha$ and $\alpha'$ one can find permutations to write $\tau \int c \, d\alpha'$ as $\sum_{i=1}^n c ( x_1^{(i)}, x_2^{(\sigma_2(i))}, \dots, x_d^{(\sigma_d(i))})$.}

\begin{definition}
A set $\Gamma \subseteq E$ is $c$-cyclically monotone if it fulfills any of the two following equivalent conditions:
\begin{enumerate}[(i)]
\item 
 for any $n$ and any points $\bigl(x_1^{(1)}, \dots, x_d^{(1)}\bigr), \dots, \bigl(x_1^{(n)}, \dots, x_d^{(n)}\bigr)\in \Gamma$ and  permutations $\sigma_2, \dots, \sigma_{d}: \{1, \dots, n \} \rightarrow \{1, \dots, n\}$, one has
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\sum_{i=1}^{n}c\bigl{(}x_{1}^{(i)},\dots,x_{d}^{(i)}\bigr{)}\leq\sum_{i=1}^{n}%
c\bigl{(}x_{1}^{(i)},x_{2}^{(\sigma_{2}(i))},\dots,x_{d}^{(\sigma_{d}(i))}%
\bigr{)}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>n</mi></munderover><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">(</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>n</mi></munderover><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">(</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
\item 
any finite measure $\alpha$  concentrated on finitely many points in $\Gamma$ is a cost-minimizing transport plan between its marginals; i.e. if $\alpha'$ has the same marginals as $\alpha$, then
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\int c\,d\alpha\leq\int c\,d\alpha^{\prime}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>c</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>c</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><msup><mi>α</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="c(x_{1},\dots,x_{d})\leq f_{1}(x_{1})+\dots+f_{d}(x_{d})~{}\text{ for all }~{}%
x_{1},\dots,x_{d}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mtext> for all </mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

2},\dots,x_{d})" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>φ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>φ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>φ</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: If $\tilde{\varphi}_1, \dots, \tilde{\varphi}_i$ are already defined, set

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\tilde{\varphi}_{1}(x_{1}^{0})=\inf_{x_{2},\dots,x_{d}}\bigl{\{}c(x_{1}^{0},x_%

\dots,x_{i},x_{i+1}^{0},x_{i+2},\dots,x_{d})" display="inline"><mrow><mo>=</mo><munder><mo movablelimits="false">inf</mo><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi></msub></mrow></munder><mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">{</mo><mi>c</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex9Xa.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\hskip 85.358268pt-\tilde{\varphi}_{1}(x_{1})-\dots-\tilde{%
\varphi}_{i}(x_{i})" display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mo lspace="87.9pt">-</mo><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>φ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>φ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

)\bigr{\}}." display="inline"><mrow><mo lspace="87.9pt">-</mo><msub><mi>φ</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>φ</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">}</mo><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

_{d}^{0})~{}\text{ for all }~{}x_{i}\in X_{i},~{}Êi=1,\dots,d." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>φ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mtext> for all </mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>X</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>Ã</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>d</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Hence, the values $\tilde{\varphi}_{i}(x_{i}^0)$ are all in $\RR$. 
Now define
\begin{eqnarray*}
\varphi_{1}: x_{1} \mapsto \tilde{\varphi}_{1} (x_{1}) + \tilde{\varphi}_{2}(x_{2}^0) + \dots + \tilde{\varphi}_{d}(x_{d}^0)Ê\\
\varphi_{i}: x_{i} \mapsto \tilde{\varphi}_{i} (x_{i}) - \tilde{\varphi}_{i}(x_{i}^0), ~\text{ for } i= 2, \dots, d.
\end{eqnarray*}
We have of $\sum_{i=1}^d \varphi_{i}(x_{i}) = \sum_{i=1}^d \tilde{\varphi}_{i}(x_{i})$, hence $(\varphi_{1}, \dots, \varphi_{d})$ is a $(G,c)$-splitting tuple with 
$\varphi_{1} (x_{1}^0) = c(x^0) \geq 0$ and $\varphi_{i}(x_{i}^0) = 0$ for $i=2, \dots, d$.
We hence have:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\sum_{i=1}^{d}\tilde{\varphi}_{i}(x_{i}^{0})=c(x^{0})." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>d</mi></munderover><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>φ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
Hence, the values $\tilde{\varphi}_{i}(x_{i}^0)$ are all in $\RR$. 
Now define
\begin{eqnarray*}
\varphi_{1}: x_{1} \mapsto \tilde{\varphi}_{1} (x_{1}) + \tilde{\varphi}_{2}(x_{2}^0) + \dots + \tilde{\varphi}_{d}(x_{d}^0)Ê\\
\varphi_{i}: x_{i} \mapsto \tilde{\varphi}_{i} (x_{i}) - \tilde{\varphi}_{i}(x_{i}^0), ~\text{ for } i= 2, \dots, d.
\end{eqnarray*}
We have of $\sum_{i=1}^d \varphi_{i}(x_{i}) = \sum_{i=1}^d \tilde{\varphi}_{i}(x_{i})$, hence $(\varphi_{1}, \dots, \varphi_{d})$ is a $(G,c)$-splitting tuple with 
$\varphi_{1} (x_{1}^0) = c(x^0) \geq 0$ and $\varphi_{i}(x_{i}^0) = 0$ for $i=2, \dots, d$.
We hence have:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\varphi_{1}(x_{1})" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>φ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex12.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\leq c(x_{1},x_{2}^{0},\dots,x_{d}^{0})~{}\text{ for all }x_{1}%
\in X_{1}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>≤</mo><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> for all </mtext><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>X</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex13.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\varphi_{i}(x_{i})" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>φ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex13.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\leq c(x_{1}^{0},\dots,x_{i-1}^{0},x_{i},x_{i+1}^{0},\dots,x_{d}^%
{0})-\varphi_{1}(x_{1}^{0})" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>≤</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>φ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex14.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\leq c(x_{1}^{0},\dots,x_{i-1}^{0},x_{i},x_{i+1}^{0},\dots,x_{d}^%
{0})~{}\text{ for all }x_{i}\in X_{i}." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>≤</mo><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> for all </mtext><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>X</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
For each finite subset $G$ of $\Gamma$, set $G' = G \cup \{ x^0 \}$. By the previous two lemmas, for each such $G'$ there is a $(G',c)$-splitting tuple with the components of the tuple bounded from above by $c_{1}, \dots, c_{d}$, respectively.
Now we define:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex15.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="c_{i}:x_{i}\mapsto c(x_{1}^{0},\dots,x_{i-1}^{0},x_{i},x_{i+1}^{0},\dots,x_{d}%
^{0})." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>c</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>:</mo><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>↦</mo><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: The sets  $\cG_{G'}$ are nonempty by our previous considerations. Note that they are closed in the topology of pointwise convergence on the \emph{compact} function space $\overline{\RR}^{X_{1}} \times \dots \times \overline{\RR}^{X_{d}}$. Also, the sets $\cG_{G'}$ have the finite intersection property: this is clear from
prevtext:
For each finite subset $G$ of $\Gamma$, set $G' = G \cup \{ x^0 \}$. By the previous two lemmas, for each such $G'$ there is a $(G',c)$-splitting tuple with the components of the tuple bounded from above by $c_{1}, \dots, c_{d}$, respectively.
Now we define:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex16.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\cG_{G}=\bigl{\{}\varphi\equiv(\varphi_{1},\dots,\varphi_{d}):%
\varphi\text{ is a }(G^{\prime},c)-\text{splitting tuple with }" display="inline"><mrow><msub><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\cG</mtext></merror><mi>G</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">{</mo><mi>φ</mi><mo>≡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>φ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>φ</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>:</mo><mi>φ</mi><mtext> is a </mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>G</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>,</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mtext>splitting tuple with</mtext></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex17.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\varphi_{i}(x_{i})\leq c_{i}(x_{i})\text{ for all }x_{i}\in X_{i}%
,i=1,\dots,d\bigr{\}}." display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>φ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>≤</mo><msub><mi>c</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mtext> for all </mtext><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>X</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>d</mi><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">}</mo><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: The sets  $\cG_{G'}$ are nonempty by our previous considerations. Note that they are closed in the topology of pointwise convergence on the \emph{compact} function space $\overline{\RR}^{X_{1}} \times \dots \times \overline{\RR}^{X_{d}}$. Also, the sets $\cG_{G'}$ have the finite intersection property: this is clear from
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex18.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\cG_{(G_{1}\cup G_{2})^{\prime}}\subseteq\cG_{G_{1}^{\prime}}\cap\cG_{G_{2}^{%
\prime}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\cG</mtext></merror><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>G</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>∪</mo><msub><mi>G</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>′</mo></msup></msub><mo>⊆</mo><mrow><msub><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\cG</mtext></merror><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mn>1</mn><mo>′</mo></msubsup></msub><mo>∩</mo><msub><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\cG</mtext></merror><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mn>2</mn><mo>′</mo></msubsup></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
is non-empty. It is easy to check that each of the tuples in $\cG$ is $(\Gamma, c)$-splitting. 
\end{proof}
\begin{proof}[Proof of Theorem 1.2.]
$\mu$ is concentrated on a $c$-cyclically monotone, and hence $c$-splitting set $\Gamma$. By the assumption on  $c$, for any  $x^0 = (x_{1}^0, \dots, x_{d}^0)$ in $\Gamma$ the functions
prevtext: Consequently, the set

are in $L_1(\mu_{i})$.
By Lemma 2.4, there is a measurable $(\Gamma, c)$-splitting tuple $(\varphi_{1}, \dots, \varphi_{d})$ such that

\begin{proof}[Proof of Theorem 1.2.]
$\mu$ is concentrated on a $c$-cyclically monotone, and hence $c$-splitting set $\Gamma$. By the assumption on  $c$, for any  $x^0 = (x_{1}^0, \dots, x_{d}^0)$ in $\Gamma$ the functions
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex20.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="c_{i}:x_{i}\mapsto c(x_{1}^{0},\dots,x_{i-1}^{0},x_{i},x_{i+1}^{0},\dots,x_{d}%
^{0})" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>c</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>:</mo><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>↦</mo><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Hence, the functions $\varphi_{i}$ are all integrable against $\mu_{i}$, with the value of the integral in $[-\infty, \infty)$. 
Now take any $\mu' \in \cM(\mu_{1}, \dots, \mu_{d})$. 
We have, as $\mu$ is concentrated on the $c$-splitting set $\Gamma$, and $(\varphi_{1}, \dots, \varphi_{d})$ is $(\Gamma, c)$-splitting:

are in $L_1(\mu_{i})$.
By Lemma 2.4, there is a measurable $(\Gamma, c)$-splitting tuple $(\varphi_{1}, \dots, \varphi_{d})$ such that
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex21.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\varphi_{i}(x_{i})\leq c_{i}(x_{i})~{}~{}\text{ for all }x_{i}\in X_{i},i=1,%
\dots,d." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>φ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mrow><msub><mi>c</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo rspace="9.1pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> for all </mtext><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>X</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>d</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
Hence, the functions $\varphi_{i}$ are all integrable against $\mu_{i}$, with the value of the integral in $[-\infty, \infty)$. 
Now take any $\mu' \in \cM(\mu_{1}, \dots, \mu_{d})$. 
We have, as $\mu$ is concentrated on the $c$-splitting set $\Gamma$, and $(\varphi_{1}, \dots, \varphi_{d})$ is $(\Gamma, c)$-splitting:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex22.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\int c\;d\mu=\sum\int\varphi_{i}\;d\mu_{i}\leq\int c\;d\mu^{\prime}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><mi>c</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><msub><mi>φ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><mi>c</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><msup><mi>μ</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>
